trans-unit.source: Microsoft is announcing changes to the billing model for <token>sb1</token>, effective November 1, 2014.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft is announcing changes to the billing model for <token>sb1</token>, effective November 1, 2014.

trans-unit.source: <token>sb2</token> will be offered in <legacyItalic>Basic</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>Standard</legacyItalic> tiers in order to align with the Basic and Standard tiers that are available for Event Hubs.
trans-unit.target: <token>sb2</token> will be offered in <legacyItalic>Basic</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>Standard</legacyItalic> tiers in order to align with the Basic and Standard tiers that are available for Event Hubs.

trans-unit.source: After the change, you can choose a service tier for each <token>sb2</token> <token>servicensd</token> that you create, and this tier selection applies across all queues, topics/subscriptions, relays, and Event Hubs created within that namespace.
trans-unit.target: After the change, you can choose a service tier for each <token>sb2</token> <token>servicensd</token> that you create, and this tier selection applies across all queues, topics/subscriptions, relays, and Event Hubs created within that namespace.

trans-unit.source: For information about current <token>sb2</token> pricing, see the <link xlink:href="812fbc90-55eb-4163-8689-ffb24aec845e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Bus Pricing FAQ</link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about current <token>sb2</token> pricing, see the <link xlink:href="812fbc90-55eb-4163-8689-ffb24aec845e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Bus Pricing FAQ</link>.

trans-unit.source: <token>sb2</token> will continue to bill messages (at current rates) for queues and topics through October 31, 2014.
trans-unit.target: <token>sb2</token> will continue to bill messages (at current rates) for queues and topics through October 31, 2014.

trans-unit.source: As part of this change, we are introducing two new meters for queues and topics/subscriptions:
trans-unit.target: As part of this change, we are introducing two new meters for queues and topics/subscriptions:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Messaging Operations</embeddedLabel>: Defined as API calls against queue or topic/subscription service endpoints.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Messaging Operations</embeddedLabel>: Defined as API calls against queue or topic/subscription service endpoints.

trans-unit.source: This meter will replace messages sent or received as the primary unit of billable usage for queues and topics/subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: This meter will replace messages sent or received as the primary unit of billable usage for queues and topics/subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Brokered Connections</embeddedLabel>: Defined as the peak number of persistent connections open against queues, topics/subscriptions, or Event Hubs during a given one-hour sampling period.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Brokered Connections</embeddedLabel>: Defined as the peak number of persistent connections open against queues, topics/subscriptions, or Event Hubs during a given one-hour sampling period.

trans-unit.source: This meter will only apply in the Standard tier, in which you can open additional connections (previously, connections were limited to 100 per queue/topic/subscription) for a nominal per-connection fee.
trans-unit.target: This meter will only apply in the Standard tier, in which you can open additional connections (previously, connections were limited to 100 per queue/topic/subscription) for a nominal per-connection fee.

trans-unit.source: The Standard tier introduces graduated pricing for operations performed with queues and topics/subscriptions, resulting in volume-based discounts of up to 80% at the highest usage levels.
trans-unit.target: The Standard tier introduces graduated pricing for operations performed with queues and topics/subscriptions, resulting in volume-based discounts of up to 80% at the highest usage levels.

trans-unit.source: We are also introducing a Standard tier base charge of $10 per month, which enables you to perform up to 12.5 million operations per month at no additional cost.
trans-unit.target: We are also introducing a Standard tier base charge of $10 per month, which enables you to perform up to 12.5 million operations per month at no additional cost.

trans-unit.source: Note that the standard base charge is charged only once per month per Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Note that the standard base charge is charged only once per month per Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: This means that after you create a single Standard tier <token>sb2</token> namespace, you will be able to create as many additional Standard tier namespaces as you want under that same Azure subscription, without incurring additional base charges.
trans-unit.target: This means that after you create a single Standard tier <token>sb2</token> namespace, you will be able to create as many additional Standard tier namespaces as you want under that same Azure subscription, without incurring additional base charges.

trans-unit.source: With the activation of the new billing model, currently scheduled for Nov 1, 2014, all existing <token>sb2</token> customers will automatically be placed into the Standard tier.
trans-unit.target: With the activation of the new billing model, currently scheduled for Nov 1, 2014, all existing <token>sb2</token> customers will automatically be placed into the Standard tier.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that you continue to have access to all features currently available with <token>sb2</token>.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that you continue to have access to all features currently available with <token>sb2</token>.

trans-unit.source: Subsequently, you can use the Azure management portal to downgrade to the Basic tier if desired.
trans-unit.target: Subsequently, you can use the Azure management portal to downgrade to the Basic tier if desired.

trans-unit.source: The following table summarizes the functional differences between the Basic and Standard tiers.
trans-unit.target: The following table summarizes the functional differences between the Basic and Standard tiers.

trans-unit.source: As part of the new pricing model, billing for queues and topics/subscriptions is changing.
trans-unit.target: As part of the new pricing model, billing for queues and topics/subscriptions is changing.

trans-unit.source: These entities are transitioning from billing per message to billing per operation.
trans-unit.target: These entities are transitioning from billing per message to billing per operation.

trans-unit.source: An "operation" refers to any API call made against a queue or topic/subscription service endpoint.
trans-unit.target: An "operation" refers to any API call made against a queue or topic/subscription service endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This includes management, send/receive, and session state operations.
trans-unit.target: This includes management, send/receive, and session state operations.

trans-unit.source: Create, Read, Update, Delete (CRUD) against queues or topics/subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Create, Read, Update, Delete (CRUD) against queues or topics/subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Sending and receiving messages with queues or topics/subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Sending and receiving messages with queues or topics/subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Getting or setting session state on a queue or topic/subscription.
trans-unit.target: Getting or setting session state on a queue or topic/subscription.

trans-unit.source: The following prices are effective starting November 1, 2014:
trans-unit.target: The following prices are effective starting November 1, 2014:

trans-unit.source: <token>sb2</token> will continue to bill messages (at current rates) for queues and topics through October 31, 2014.
trans-unit.target: <token>sb2</token> will continue to bill messages (at current rates) for queues and topics through October 31, 2014.

trans-unit.source: We are introducing the concept of <newTerm>brokered connections</newTerm> to accommodate customer usage patterns that involve a large number of “persistently connected” senders/receivers against queues, topics/subscriptions or Event Hubs.
trans-unit.target: We are introducing the concept of <newTerm>brokered connections</newTerm> to accommodate customer usage patterns that involve a large number of “persistently connected” senders/receivers against queues, topics/subscriptions or Event Hubs.

trans-unit.source: Persistently connected senders/receivers are those that connect using either AMQP or HTTP with a non-zero receive timeout (for example, HTTP long polling).
trans-unit.target: Persistently connected senders/receivers are those that connect using either AMQP or HTTP with a non-zero receive timeout (for example, HTTP long polling).

trans-unit.source: HTTP senders and receivers with an immediate timeout will not generate brokered connections.
trans-unit.target: HTTP senders and receivers with an immediate timeout will not generate brokered connections.

trans-unit.source: Previously, queues and topics/subscriptions had a limit of 100 concurrent connections per URL.
trans-unit.target: Previously, queues and topics/subscriptions had a limit of 100 concurrent connections per URL.

trans-unit.source: The current billing change removes the per-URL limit for queues and topics/subscriptions, and implements quotas and metering on brokered connections at the <token>sb2</token> namespace and Azure subscription levels.
trans-unit.target: The current billing change removes the per-URL limit for queues and topics/subscriptions, and implements quotas and metering on brokered connections at the <token>sb2</token> namespace and Azure subscription levels.

trans-unit.source: The Basic tier includes, and is strictly limited to, 100 brokered connections per <token>sb2</token> namespace.
trans-unit.target: The Basic tier includes, and is strictly limited to, 100 brokered connections per <token>sb2</token> namespace.

trans-unit.source: Connections above this number will be rejected in the Basic tier.
trans-unit.target: Connections above this number will be rejected in the Basic tier.

trans-unit.source: The Standard tier removes the per-namespace limit and counts aggregate brokered connection usage across the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The Standard tier removes the per-namespace limit and counts aggregate brokered connection usage across the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In the Standard tier, 1,000 brokered connections per Azure subscription will be allowed at no extra cost (beyond the base charge).
trans-unit.target: In the Standard tier, 1,000 brokered connections per Azure subscription will be allowed at no extra cost (beyond the base charge).

trans-unit.source: Using more than a total of 1,000 brokered connections across Standard-tier <token>sb2</token> namespaces in an Azure subscription will be billed on a graduated schedule, as shown in the following table.
trans-unit.target: Using more than a total of 1,000 brokered connections across Standard-tier <token>sb2</token> namespaces in an Azure subscription will be billed on a graduated schedule, as shown in the following table.

trans-unit.source: 1,000 brokered connections are included with the Standard messaging tier (via the base charge) and can be shared across all queues, topics/subscriptions and Event Hubs within the associated Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: 1,000 brokered connections are included with the Standard messaging tier (via the base charge) and can be shared across all queues, topics/subscriptions and Event Hubs within the associated Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Billing is based on the peak number of concurrent connections and is prorated hourly based on 744 hours per month.
trans-unit.target: Billing is based on the peak number of concurrent connections and is prorated hourly based on 744 hours per month.

trans-unit.source: For more information about brokered connections, see the FAQ section later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information about brokered connections, see the FAQ section later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: As previously noted, relays will be available only in Standard tier namespaces.
trans-unit.target: As previously noted, relays will be available only in Standard tier namespaces.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, pricing and connection quotas for relays remain unchanged.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, pricing and connection quotas for relays remain unchanged.

trans-unit.source: This means that relays will continue to be charged on the number of messages (not operations), and relay hours.
trans-unit.target: This means that relays will continue to be charged on the number of messages (not operations), and relay hours.

trans-unit.source: How is the Relay Hours meter calculated?
trans-unit.target: How is the Relay Hours meter calculated?

trans-unit.source: What are brokered connections and how do I get charged for them?
trans-unit.target: What are brokered connections and how do I get charged for them?

trans-unit.source: A brokered connection is defined as one of the following:
trans-unit.target: A brokered connection is defined as one of the following:

trans-unit.source: An AMQP connection from a client to a <token>sb2</token> topic/subscription, queue, or Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: An AMQP connection from a client to a <token>sb2</token> topic/subscription, queue, or Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: An HTTP call to receive a message from a <token>sb2</token> topic or queue that has a receive timeout value greater than zero.
trans-unit.target: An HTTP call to receive a message from a <token>sb2</token> topic or queue that has a receive timeout value greater than zero.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft charges for the peak number of concurrent brokered connections that exceed the included quantity (1,000 in the Standard tier).
trans-unit.target: Microsoft charges for the peak number of concurrent brokered connections that exceed the included quantity (1,000 in the Standard tier).

trans-unit.source: Peaks are measured on an hourly basis, prorated by dividing by 744 hours in a month, and added up over the monthly billing period.
trans-unit.target: Peaks are measured on an hourly basis, prorated by dividing by 744 hours in a month, and added up over the monthly billing period.

trans-unit.source: The included quantity (1,000 brokered connections per month) is applied at the end of the billing period against the sum of the prorated hourly peaks.
trans-unit.target: The included quantity (1,000 brokered connections per month) is applied at the end of the billing period against the sum of the prorated hourly peaks.

trans-unit.source: Each of 10,000 devices connect via a single AMQP connection, and receive commands from a <token>sb2</token> topic.
trans-unit.target: Each of 10,000 devices connect via a single AMQP connection, and receive commands from a <token>sb2</token> topic.

trans-unit.source: The devices send telemetry events to an Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: The devices send telemetry events to an Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: If all devices connect for 12 hours each day, the following connection charges apply (in addition to any other <token>sb2</token> topic charges): 10,000 connections * 12 hours * 31 days / 744 = 5,000 brokered connections.
trans-unit.target: If all devices connect for 12 hours each day, the following connection charges apply (in addition to any other <token>sb2</token> topic charges): 10,000 connections * 12 hours * 31 days / 744 = 5,000 brokered connections.

trans-unit.source: After the monthly allowance of 1,000 brokered connections, you would be charged for 4,000 brokered connections, at the rate of $0.03 per brokered connection, for a total of $120.
trans-unit.target: After the monthly allowance of 1,000 brokered connections, you would be charged for 4,000 brokered connections, at the rate of $0.03 per brokered connection, for a total of $120.

trans-unit.source: 10,000 devices receive messages from a <token>sb2</token> queue via HTTP, specifying a non-zero timeout.
trans-unit.target: 10,000 devices receive messages from a <token>sb2</token> queue via HTTP, specifying a non-zero timeout.

trans-unit.source: If all devices connect for 12 hours every day, you will see the following connection charges (in addition to any other <token>sb2</token> charges): 10,000 HTTP Receive connections * 12 hours per day * 31 days / 744 hours = 5,000 brokered connections.
trans-unit.target: If all devices connect for 12 hours every day, you will see the following connection charges (in addition to any other <token>sb2</token> charges): 10,000 HTTP Receive connections * 12 hours per day * 31 days / 744 hours = 5,000 brokered connections.

trans-unit.source: Do brokered connection charges apply to queues and topics/subscriptions?
trans-unit.target: Do brokered connection charges apply to queues and topics/subscriptions?

trans-unit.source: There are no connection charges for sending events using HTTP, regardless of the number of sending systems or devices.
trans-unit.target: There are no connection charges for sending events using HTTP, regardless of the number of sending systems or devices.

trans-unit.source: Receiving events with HTTP using a timeout greater than zero, sometimes called “long polling,” generates brokered connection charges.
trans-unit.target: Receiving events with HTTP using a timeout greater than zero, sometimes called “long polling,” generates brokered connection charges.

trans-unit.source: AMQP connections generate brokered connection charges regardless of whether the connections are being used to send or receive.
trans-unit.target: AMQP connections generate brokered connection charges regardless of whether the connections are being used to send or receive.

trans-unit.source: Note that 100 brokered connections are allowed at no charge in a Basic namespace.
trans-unit.target: Note that 100 brokered connections are allowed at no charge in a Basic namespace.

trans-unit.source: This is also the maximum number of brokered connections allowed for the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: This is also the maximum number of brokered connections allowed for the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: The first 1,000 brokered connections across all Standard namespaces in an Azure subscription are included at no extra charge (beyond the base charge).
trans-unit.target: The first 1,000 brokered connections across all Standard namespaces in an Azure subscription are included at no extra charge (beyond the base charge).

trans-unit.source: Because these allowances are enough to cover many service-to-service messaging scenarios, brokered connection charges usually only become relevant if you plan to use AMQP or HTTP long-polling with a large number of clients; for example, to achieve more efficient event streaming or enable bi-directional communication with many devices or application instances.
trans-unit.target: Because these allowances are enough to cover many service-to-service messaging scenarios, brokered connection charges usually only become relevant if you plan to use AMQP or HTTP long-polling with a large number of clients; for example, to achieve more efficient event streaming or enable bi-directional communication with many devices or application instances.
